content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clash, not too difficult but tricky enough to make it fun.
I've asked for a small edit, but it's not really significant enough to delay approval.

Pretty diabolical, but solvable if you think laterally enough to see what's happening.

Only thing I think needs changing is the test case named "Chain rule", that name makes it seem like something more complicated is going on and threw me off on a tangent for a bit when I tried solving this under Reverse conditions.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Not complicated in itself, but it takes a little time to get the logic.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The main problem is finding exactly what is asked, it may take a few minutes, but after we find, the solution is pretty easy to code and should not require very advanced tools, while requiring certain bases.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Not sure if it's a bug, but the first input in the 'word' variable is empty. The base code keeps displaying an error, and my code is unable to function as a result. Also, in testcase 7, it says the error is on line 17, the 'sentencelen' variable.

Here's the error message: 
Exception in thread "main" java.util.NoSuchElementException: No line found
at java.base/java.util.Scanner.nextLine on line 1651
at Solution.main on line 15
Update: I added two cases on May 20th at 2:30.

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement, e.g. "write answer".

Thanks.

Apparently the language assist on the base code warns that "in" is never closed? I'm not sure what that means but it warns of a resource leak.
In no other language does it warn about a genuine risk, just unused variables.
I'm pretty sure that's a bug.
I'd assume this would be a name change, but what would be a better name for it?

Even just "Word chain" would be less confusing, I think?

Also, just as a heads up, no one will see the names you've given to the validators once this is published, only the test cases will be visible to clashers.
In the Java version, I changed "in.nextLine()" to "in.next()" and it was fixed. So, I guess it was just how Java handles input.

I figured it out. Apparently I tried using strings in a loopline instead of words in the stub generator. So, the program was told it needed to split the sentence into parts, but the strings don't allow any character to be marked as the one to split with.

Basically, the stub generator's code tried splitting something that can't be split.
